p: Among the studied terpenes, D (+) limonene exhibited the best IC 50 on Tryp (IC 50 9 ± 0.8 μg/mL, SI = 32.8, p < 0.05), and Amas (IC 50 29 ± 0.7 μg/mL, SI = 10.3, p < 0.05) forms, (Table 5, Fig. 2b), with the most selective and the least toxic performance on mammal cells (CC 50 297 ± 2.4 μg/mL, and SI = 7.1, p < 0.05), with a CC 50 even lower than the reference drug (BNZ: CC 50 139 ± 2.3 μg/mL). At the other end of the spectrum, S (+) carvone constituted the terpene with the worst trypanocidal activity on all evolutionary T. cruzi forms (Epi: IC 50 177 ± 7.9 μg/mL, and SI = 1.4; Tryp: IC 50 124 ± 7.8 μg/mL, and SI = 1.9; Amas: IC 50 > 100 μg/mL) (Table 5). It is worth pointing out that all the terpenoid fractions, except carvone, were able to induce significant cell death on extracellular forms of the parasite at 50 μg/mL (Epi: CDP = 66 ± 1.9%; Tryp: CDP = 90 ± 1.2%, p < 0.05) with caryophyllene oxide being the terpene with the highest rate of death on Epi (78 ± 2.3%), and Tryp (98 ± 0.5%, p < 0.05).
